block.p: International 2-6 HAITIAN MARCH TURNS VIOLENT Gunmen backing army rule scattered a demonstration of Aristide supporters as American soldiers, deployed blocks away in tanks surrounded by barbed wire, did nothing to stop the violence. 1 U.S. RELUCTANCE IN HAITI After two days of bloodshed, the United States finds its mission to install democracy jeopardized by its reluctance to disarm government paramilitary gunmen. 1 U.S. PLANNING IS FAULTED Planning to maintain order after the entry of American forces has been improvised and at times confused, critics and even some Administration officials say. 4 For decades, Fort Dimanche was Haiti's chamber of horrors. 5 ARAB BOYCOTT IS PARTLY LIFTED Saudi Arabia and its five Persian Gulf partners announced a partial lifting of the 46-year-old Arab boycott of Israel and a pledge to urge the rest of the Arab world to drop the trade ban. 1 CAUSE OF SINKING STILL UNCLEAR Swedish officials said they believed that the bow door of an Estonian ferry opened or was never properly closed on its last voyage. But the cause of the disaster remains uncertain. 6 The Swedish town of Norrkoping was hit hard by the disaster.6 TENSION RISES IN ALGERIA The civil turmoil pitting secularists against Muslim militants in Algeria widened with the slaying of a well-known Berber singer. 3 FRENCH H.I.V. SCANDAL WIDENS Two years after minor French officials were jailed for knowingly distributing blood contaminated with H.I.V., a former Socialist Prime Minister is under investigation as an alleged accomplice. 3 Dakar Journal: Linked to Internet, could Africa's voice be heard? 2

International 2-6 HAITIAN MARCH TURNS VIOLENT Gunmen backing army rule scattered a demonstration of Aristide supporters as American soldiers, deployed blocks away in tanks surrounded by barbed wire, did nothing to stop the violence. 1 U.S. RELUCTANCE IN HAITI After two days of bloodshed, the United States finds its mission to install democracy jeopardized by its reluctance to disarm government paramilitary gunmen. 1 U.S. PLANNING IS FAULTED Planning to maintain order after the entry of American forces has been improvised and at times confused, critics and even some Administration officials say. 4 For decades, Fort Dimanche was Haiti's chamber of horrors. 5 ARAB BOYCOTT IS PARTLY LIFTED Saudi Arabia and its five Persian Gulf partners announced a partial lifting of the 46-year-old Arab boycott of Israel and a pledge to urge the rest of the Arab world to drop the trade ban. 1 CAUSE OF SINKING STILL UNCLEAR Swedish officials said they believed that the bow door of an Estonian ferry opened or was never properly closed on its last voyage. But the cause of the disaster remains uncertain. 6 The Swedish town of Norrkoping was hit hard by the disaster.6 TENSION RISES IN ALGERIA The civil turmoil pitting secularists against Muslim militants in Algeria widened with the slaying of a well-known Berber singer. 3 FRENCH H.I.V. SCANDAL WIDENS Two years after minor French officials were jailed for knowingly distributing blood contaminated with H.I.V., a former Socialist Prime Minister is under investigation as an alleged accomplice. 3 Dakar Journal: Linked to Internet, could Africa's voice be heard? 2
CAMPAIGN FINANCE BILL KILLED A bill overhauling the financing of Congressional campaigns joined health care

in the legislative graveyard of the 103d Congress. 1 How senators voted on the campaign finance bill filibuster. 9 FUND-RAISER IN CHIEF In 20 months, President Clinton has personally raised $40 million in Democratic political donations -- nearly half the national party's reported total. 9 SOUR MOOD ON CAPITOL HILL With just days left in this session, Republicans are determined to foil almost every Democratic measure as they flex their muscles and savor predictions of big Democratic losses in November. 1 SURGERY CUTS RISK OF STROKE A controversial operation to remove fatty deposits from an artery in the neck sharply reduced the risk of stroke, scientists reported. 1 QUESTIONS FOR SIMPSON JURY Potential jurors are being asked a laundry list of questions about everything from ownership of knives to their impressions of O. J. Simpson's television commercials. 7 SETTLEMENT IN G.M. STRIKE General Motors and the U.A.W. tentatively settled a three-day-old strike that threatened to shut down North American production. 7 SHUTTLE ON RADAR MISSION The Endeavour was launched and began sweeping Earth with advanced radars to detect and monitor environmental changes. 7 BUDGET SCARE IN WASHINGTON Only minutes after the Mayor announced plans to shut down Washington's government, the Senate approved a $660 million appropriation to keep the district running. 8 CRACKDOWN ON ILLEGAL ALIENS A Federal commission recommended tough measures to stop illegal immigration, including a computerized employment registry and denying services to illegal aliens. 8 QUAYLE CAMPAIGNS FOR NORTH A former Vice President warmly endorsed a former Iran-contra plotter in Virginia's Senate Race. 9 ENOLA GAY EXHIBIT CHANGED After months of heated criticism, the Smithsonian Institution agreed to change its exhibit of the airplane that dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima. 10 Religion: Alternative medicine's rise cheers Christian Scientists. 30

N.H.L. DELAYS START OF SEASON The National Hockey League locked out its players for at least the first two weeks of the season. 1 Baseball: Attempt to challenge antitrust exemption is blocked. 34 Basketball: Knicks hoping to work out a deal with Oakley. 36 Boxing: A war of words before Whitaker-McGirt title fight. 36 Columns: Rhoden on lockout. 33 On Hockey 33 Football: Meet the new Jets, same as the old Jets. 33 Giants' Howard is not shy about speaking up. 36 Walsh, Stanford's rare coach, takes on Notre Dame. 37 Hockey: Bettman a lightning rod as N.H.L. postpones season. 33 Rangers give Richter a raise as they hear the news. 35 Sports People 37 Metro Digest 25 Business Digest 41 Arts/Entertainment 11-18 Film: "Theremin: An Electronic Odyssey." 11 "See How They Fall." 12 "A Confucian Confusion." 12 Music: Ned Rorem's intrigue with opera. 11 Bruce Cockburn. 11 Bartoli at Carnegie Hall. 14 Obituaries 31 Dr. Archer Gordon, heart specialist. Editorials/Op-Ed 22-23 Editorials A truce to help New York City. Milking the poor. Getting to yes with North Korea. Corruption in the "Dirty 30." Letters Anna Quindlen: Don't read this. Russell Baker: Do them yourself. Daniel Strong: Generation hex. Francis Ghiles: Last chance in Algeria. Bridge 18 Chronicle 24 Crossword 16
